column3: <font color='peru'>Okay. Marilyn, let me ask you: you've lived in New England and Lower Connecticut, though you were not born there, you're Midwesterner by birth. How do you see that part of the country</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>Well, the last couple of writing projects I've done have been picking up stories from Connecticut history, actually, African American History in New England. I've just finished writing</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>a long sequence of poems about an 18th century slave who lived in a small city in Connecticut and who, when he died-- he was owned by a doctor,  and when he died the doctor prepared his skeleton, and</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>reassembled the bones and hung the skeleton in a room in his home, to be used as a teaching device. To teach people about skeletons, human bones. And meanwhile this man, Fortune was his name, his wife</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>and four children were still in this household.</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>Yes, this is in Connecticut, just before the American Revolution. So that's one, that one's just come out. And--</font>
It's called Fortune's Bones. And I have another project that's cooking on a back-burner now, about another man who was enslaved in the 18th century in Connecticut, and who

<font color='rebeccapurple'>managed to purchase his own freedom and then purchased all of the members of his family,  and then several other people. And is kind of a local hero.   He's very highly respected. He died in about, oh,</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>gosh, maybe 1790. Something like that. So I suppose what I'm doing is telling local history stories.</font>
<font color='peru'>So the stories that you want people to know about that part of the country, but are about Black people in that part of the country</font>

<font color='peru'>But you could you could write those stories in any part of the country, at least based on the local history of that part of the country, right? So in a sense, you're not-- you don't</font>
<font color='peru'>fall into the sense of place. You do have sense of place, but you have sense of history, which is probably--</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>Yes, I suppose what it is is sense of history. In the Fortune story, I was asked to write it by a local historical museum. But I would have written it if I had been living in Kansas.</font>

<font color='black'>I've noticed also that you have, I guess like many writers, moved to another genre. Your last book has been-- has won a Children's Book Award. Can you tell me a little bit about why</font>
<font color='black'>that decision was made? And you see doing more in the children's literature genre?</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>It's not really a question of genre. It's a question of marketing. The poems have not changed. Yeah, yeah. I haven't, the poems, I'm still writing the same poems. I've I haven't</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>changed my sense of audience at all. But I've-- for a couple of my books, I've moved to a different publisher. And the books are being marketed differently. And I think of this in several ways. First</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>of all, there's a very large market for young adult books, and there are not very many poets writing, publishing for that market. And secondly, I feel the-- giving young people real poems to read is a</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>way of encouraging them to continue, to continue to be readers of poetry. So I think I'm writing for future generations of poetry readers, helping to create future poetry readers. And I think that's</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>about-- I think that's about all I can say about it. I really don't believe I've changed my writing at all.</font>
<font color='black'>Yeah. So you're-- a form, a different form in which you have placed it.</font>
<font color='black'>--Graham, it's okay but honey, just pull your blouse, so it's not just--</font>
<font color='black'>Down further, from the top, yeah.</font>

<font color='black'>Oh, I can see it. Yes. Okay. Thank you for getting it. At Furious Flower, there's a lot of discussion about regenerating tradition. And I just heard you talk about putting the tradition of poetry</font>

<font color='black'>writing back into the-- into the schools or giving children poetry from the ground up as it were. So, the notion of poetry as a tradition-- is it something you grew up with? Did you grow up reading</font>
<font color='black'>poetry? Did you [inaudible] a lot of your family, did you learn poems that you had to say in church, or?</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>I didn't have to say, or I didn't learn poems for church, but I grew up in a family which read poetry. And I grew up encouraged to read and write poetry when I was one of these</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>hypersensitive children. And I cried at the drop of a hat. Beautiful sunset, I would, would reduce me to tears. And my mother always told people don't worry about Marilyn, she's our poet. She's very</font>
<font color='peru'>So they gave you that label. I see, okay, okay.</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>Yes, yes, yes. So that's my sense of tradition. But one of the things I have been struggling to do in the last few years is to return to some of the traditional forms of poetry. I</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>So you're listening to your audience?</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>mean, they're European forms, but they're traditions that for several generations of African Americans have inherited. And so I've been writing in rhyme and meter again. And I think that's what-- I</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>started doing it for many reasons. But one of the reasons was that I kept meeting people who would say, 'I used to like poetry, but I can't tell why poems are poems now. They seem like prose to me.</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>Yeah, yeah, I'm trying to, trying to.</font>

<font color='peru'>We've been talking today a lot about why poets write and, that is, what are the factors that figure into the process, whether it's audience or whether it's the market, so clearly you</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>To audience. It seems to me to be important to be writing for somebody. For people I-- when I was in my 20s, I had-- one of my great uncle's was the president of Kentucky State. And he</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>was the patriarch of the family. And I used to send him poems and I sent him a batch of poems when I was in college, I think I was about a sophomore in college. And he wrote a very sweet letter back</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>asking me why young poets nowadays don't write poems that people like me can understand. And I thought, that's a really good question. Why shouldn't I be writing for someone? What kind of audience are</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>we looking for, are we imagining if it's not this man? So I completely changed and started working hard on writing accessible poems.</font>
<font color='peru'>Well, the first poetry that you were writing, though, was not in this vein.</font>

<font color='peru'>So were there influences that you were, you know, that you saw in that poetry where people whose work you respected-- was it the train-- the MFA program that sent you in that</font>
<font color='peru'>direction? What got you started in that line? And then, clearly, the shift occurs later.</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>No, I don't have an MFA, I didn't go to a writing program. And I think it was just, I was an English major,</font>
<font color='peru'>Yeah. And we do teach English [inaudible].</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>and I was sitting in classes where we were analyzing things to death. And I was trying to write things that could be analyzed to death. And it took a while to realize that that's not</font>

<font color='black'>But the critics like that, because you've got awards, you've got nominations for national book awards. So clearly that tradition of writing was successful for you, if you want to use</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>Although I hope that all of my published poems-- I mean this incident that I described happened before I was publishing, and I hope that the work I've published is accessible. I've</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>really struggled with that, trying to reach out to an audience to tell my little truths to a big audience.</font>

<font color='peru'>A loaded question: what is your sense of where Black poetry is today? I hear what you say about what you want to do in terms of audience. What's your sense of where we are today? Are</font>
<font color='peru'>we having a bigger impact? Are we-- do we have serious poets among us that we can look forward to another generation or so poetry, or, just how would you sum it up?</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>I'm not sure if I can sum it up because I don't have my finger on-- you'd have to have your finger on many pulses to be able to answer this question. One of the things that I think has</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>happened is that we, as-- if there was a movement, the Black Arts Movement, for example, it's become fragmented. Because so many, so many young poets now are studying in MFA programs where there are</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>only one or two African American students, maybe one African American poet teaching them. So that we're divided, and a conference like Furious Flower is really important, because it brings people</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>together, they're-- we need to have this kind of communication. I've been very, very much moved by teaching in the Cave Canem program for that reason, because it brings people together. So we have a</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>dialogue, we can discover what we have in common, we can work together in similar directions. I don't think we want to all be marching lockstep, but I think we can grow by exchanging ideas.</font>

<font color='black'>So the diffusion and dispersal effect, you think, has not necessarily been-- it may have provided good training for people but it may not have done a lot to nurture or, you know, a</font>
<font color='peru'>That's interesting. I'm going to have to stop. I'm enjoying this, and I wanna keep going. But I gotta stop.</font>
<font color='black'>Thank you. Oh, oh, if you just talk to each other, it's to get wide shots, for 30 seconds. Just talk, just say anything.</font>
<font color='peru'>Well, I was just, I had all these other questions I wanted to ask</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>No, I know you have to run though.</font>
<font color='black'>I asked a question about genre. But is there another form that you, you know, are thinking of writing in?</font>

<font color='black'>Well I mean, the poetry, as you say-- children's literature is another form, that's what I'm talking about-- genre. In that sense, I don't want to use the word genre, because of the</font>

<font color='black'>way you explained it. But would you do, for instance, plays? Would you want to, you know, write-- because the poet, poetic voice can also be there. And so that other genre is--</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>I would like to, but I have a sister who writes plays and directs them. So I've been very careful not to step over into her territory.</font>

<font color='rebeccapurple'>Yes, yes. We did work together on a musical and with our brother who's a musician. She wrote the book. And she wrote some of the lyrics, and I wrote some of the lyrics and he did the</font>
<font color='rebeccapurple'>music. But otherwise, I feel like I'll stay-- I'll respect our boundaries.</font>
<font color='peru'>You'll stay where you are. Yeah. That's right, yeah.</font>
<font color='black'>That is the thing with sisters, you know, you do--</font>
